VIII.ii.2.B.1.a
.
Identifying a Claim for Qualifying Disabilities Due to BPOT Exposure
Claims processors should sympathetically read claims from Veterans whose symptoms and service suggest potential entitlement to presumptive service connection (SC) based on exposure to burn pits and other toxins, including fine particulate matter (BPOT).  Veterans with service in a qualifying BPOT location who claim a disability or symptom related to a disability recognized under
38 U.S.C. 1120
,
38 CFR 3.320a
, or
38 CFR 3.320b
do not need to specifically claim BPOT exposure.
Example
:  The Veteran may
identify symptoms of a general medical condition, such as shortness of breath or respiratory issues rather than explicitly listing a diagnosis, or
describe respiratory cancer in other terms, such as cancer of the throat or neck.
Notes
:
If a claim is unclear, claims processors should review the medical evidence to determine if a qualifying diagnosis exists, or follow the procedures in
M21-1, Part III, Subpart i, 2.D.1.c
to clarify the claim.
If the Veteran claims a disability that is not recognized as a BPOT presumptive, process the claim under direct SC guidelines in accordance with the toxic exposure risk activity procedures outlined in the
Sergeant First Class Heath Robinson Honoring our Promise to Address Comprehensive Toxics (PACT) Act of 2022 Implementation Standard Operating Procedure (SOP)
.
The claimant must identify the disability(ies) that resulted from BPOT exposure.  If the claimant only alleges exposure without identifying a symptom or disability, follow the procedures for handling an incomplete application in
M21-1, Part II, Subpart iii, 1.C.2.b and c
.
